awd_abstract_narration:
Maria Wimberly is awarded a Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and education at the University of California, Riverside. She plans a study of near–field cosmology and numerical modeling of galactic star formation.  She has extensive experience with hydrodynamic simulations that include star formation models. These models yield different predictions of heavy element production in ultra–faint dwarf galaxies, which depend on the environment where the stars formed. She will improve the Cal–Bridge Scholarship’s peer mentorship program, to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in Physics & Astronomy by strengthening genuine camaraderie.  The program includes specific personalized professional development planning for these young, diverse scientists. 

Wimberley will compare models of predicted element abundances to observations of galaxies in different environments, to determine which physical processes are most important in these environments. A key question she seeks to answer is what fraction of the Milky Way’s ultra–faint dwarf galaxies were never satellites of other smaller galaxy systems, prior to entering the Milky Way’s system. She seeks to learn what fraction of the Milky Way’s satellite galaxies are true, pristine relics of the first galaxies ever formed.  These galaxies are optimal sites to search for signatures of the first stars ever formed.  Within the expanded Cal-Bridge program, she plans a vertical mentoring structure.  These peer mentorship activities provide space for students to create a community around equity through normalizing common struggles, individual holistic success, and determining how to improve their academic experience. This type of group work/mentoring organically creates leadership opportunities and a thriving community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a Postdoctoral Fellowship which supported the postdoctoral scholar for 20 months prior to her successful acceptance and transition into a tenure-track faculty position. Dr. Wimberly’s work focused on observational Near Field Cosmology and peer mentorship primarily amongst students from historically underrepresented groups in STEM. 


Observational Near Field Cosmology: With the aim of uncovering what fraction of the Milky Way’s satellite galaxies are true, pristine relics of the first galaxies ever formed, Dr. Wimberly studied 7 ultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs), all satellites of the Milky Way, within the award period. Analysis was completed for 10 stars in the UFD, Hydrus I. While the majority of the results fall in line with the 19 other deeply analyzed UFDs, there are some emergent trends, especially amongst alpha and iron-peak elements, which indicate environmental dependence on chemical composition and possibly variations in the galactic initial mass function at the smallest mass scales. Observations using DEIMOS (DEep Imaging Multi-Object Spectrograph) on the Keck II telescope and data reduction was completed for 17 stars in another UFD, Willman 1. This UFD lives in a different host environment than Hydrus I, making these two research subjects the perfect pair to later compare the environmental differences as seen through the chemical abundances. 

Furthering this work, the relationship between the metallicities and stellar masses of Milky Way’s satellite galaxies is not well defined at the faintest (tiniest) end of the spectrum. To better define the physical characteristics of these UFDs and determine if they are globular clusters, full galaxies, or stripped galactic remnants, two University of California Observatory proposals were submitted and approved to observe 4 UFDs using LRIS (Low Resolution Imaging Spectrometer) on the Keck I telescope. Draco II and Bootes II were observed during the award period. Cetus II and Triangulum II were observed just after the award period ended. A similar campaign was joined and conducted observing Segue 1. Through initial analysis, some chemical abundances and metallicity can be measured from the obtained lower resolution data. This work will not only help resolve the evolutionary histories of these tiny stellar systems, potential relic galaxies, but will also help lay the groundwork for this type of science to be conducted on similar lower resolution instruments, which are more commonly available.


Cal-Bridge Program Mentorship: Dr. Wimberly’s work to broaden the participation of students from historically underrepresented groups in STEM (SHUGS) focused on improving the mentorship structures and applications within the California State University–to–University of California state–wide STEM program, Cal-Bridge. As lead author, she published a peer-reviewed journal article on the specific mentorship model used within Cal-Bridge, which is particularly effective in supporting SHUGS to succeed in academia (a system decidedly not built to support them).

Additionally, over the reporting period, Dr. Wimberly co-developed and co-facilitated a two-day long pedagogy workshop and one-day long peer mentorship and networking activities for the Cal-Bridge Doctoral Scholar Summer Institute. She created a mentorship workshop geared toward academic and research mentors, graduate and undergraduate peer mentors, and mentees at all stages focusing on relationship-based mentoring for the Inaugural Cal-Bridge Conference. Within the Cal-Bridge Peer Mentorship Program she created as a graduate student, she organized 1-on-1 mentoring discussions; led 2 optional peer mentorship workshops; created, administered and analyzed 2 evaluation surveys; led 2 mandatory socio-emotional workshops (Growth Mindset and Attending PhD School); advised faculty mentors in the creation of a Science Communication Workshop; and recruited and fully on-boarded an Assistant Director for the Peer Mentorship Program. Dr. Wimberly is now the Director of Mentorship for this state-wide program. 


Peer Mentorship within the Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of California, Riverside: Within her postdoctoral home institution, Dr. Wimberly advised a team of 5 graduate students in creating their own peer mentorship program – PAPER Mentorship (Physics And Astronomy PEeR Mentorship). This group held 3 workshops (Stressing Less, Getting Started with Research, and Comprehensive Exam Practice) and 1 long standing summer activity (Accountability Groups). She led the team in creating presentation, evaluation, and administrative templates and infrastructure to aid in institutionalizing the program. As well as, guided current leaders on how to smoothly change leadership for the program to continue operation. Additionally, Dr. Wimberly assisted in 4 faculty-led mentoring workshops (Networking, Writing Process Development, Career Development, and Academic Job Market), each geared towards the physics and astronomy graduate students.
